title: Police investigate brawling NRL fans at finals match
text:
P﻿olice are investigating a brawl last night between rival rugby league fans during an NRL finals match in southern Sydney.

Supporters traded blows during the Cronulla Sharks versus Sydney Roosters elimination final encounter at Shark Park.

Police and stewards were forced to step in to separate the brawling fans inside the stadium.

Police are investigating a brawl between NRL fans at Shark Park in Sydney. (Nine)

NSW Police said in a statement today that investigations have started.

"An investigation is underway after a brawl involving up to 10 people broke out within the grounds of a football stadium in Cronulla last night.

"Police have commenced inquiries into the circumstances surrounding the incident."

Anyone with mobile phone footage or information is urged to call Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000.

title: These siblings started a business with a few hundred bucks. It's made $20 million
text:
Nearly three years ago, siblings Maddy and Dylan Jarvis invested a few hundred dollars of their personal savings into a quirky business idea.

Now Candy Claws, their press-on nail brand, is about to hit $20 million in sales.

﻿It's a milestone most Australians who start side hustles never hit.

Siblings Maddy and Dylan Jarvis started their press-on nail brand with a few hundred dollars. It's made $20 million in sales since. (Supplied)

A 2024 report showed that, of the 55 per cent of Aussies who hoped to start a small business or side hustle by 2030, most were motivated by the idea of a better income.

But Maddy, 26, just wanted a way out of her dull corporate job when she and Dylan started Candy Claws.﻿

"It was my first corporate job out of uni, and I was really young," she told 9news.com.au.

"I'd always wanted to do my own thing, so I was like, 'I'm just going to start it now and see how it goes.'"

Looking for an extra buck? These are Australia's top side hustles View Gallery

The idea for a press-on nail business struck her in the aisles of her local chemist.

Like many young Aussies, ﻿Maddy couldn't ﻿afford to get her nails done at a salon every few weeks in a cost-of-living crisis.

But the ﻿press-ons available at her local shopping centre looked cheap, felt flimsy and fell off within a few hours.

"I was like, what if you could create press-ons that looked and felt like a salon manicure, and lasted weeks rather than days?" she said.

Dylan, 30, was totally on board with the idea.

The siblings started looking into manufacturers right away and pooled a few hundred dollars from their savings accounts to pay for the first batch of Candy Claws nails.

Orders started coming in soon after.

Maddy spent ages packing orders by hand in Candy Claws' early days. (Supplied)

By that stage, Maddy had quit her corporate job, so she had all stock delivered to her place, where she packed thousands of orders in her living room.

﻿"I couldn't even get through my front door some days when we just got a stock order in," she laughed, but the inconvenience quickly paid off.

As soon as the first batch of nails sold out, she and Dylan invested all their earnings into paying for the next batch.

Within the first month, Candy Claws had made $6000 in sales.

By the end of the first year, it had hit $1 million.

Now the business is approaching the $20 million mark, has moved into a proper warehouse and office, and Maddy and Dylan are both working on it full-time.

The brand has also ﻿expanded to New Zealand and the UK, with plans to explore the US market in the future – hopefully once the Trump administration's import tariffs have been lifted.

Maddy and Dylan have since moved the business into a proper warehouse space. (Supplied)

So what made it work when so many side hustles fail?﻿

According to Maddy, it was hard work, careful money moves, and ﻿investing in social media advertising.

"We couldn't really afford to hire content creators at the start," she said.

"So I just accepted that I was going to have to be the one to get in front of the camera and talk about the brand [and] we quickly picked up on the fact that that's what people liked."﻿

Now they have more than 70,000 Instagram followers.

Founder-forward brands can do extremely well on social media, where small business and entrepreneurial content has been booming of late.

Press-on﻿ nails have also enjoyed a massive spike in popularity recently, both online and in Aussie shopping carts.

Candy Claws has more than 70,000 Instagram followers and a huge customer base now. (Supplied)

The global press-on nail market size was estimated at $US696.6 million ($1 billion) in 2023 and is projected to hit $US1 billion by 2030, according to Grand View Research.

More than ﻿2.6 million TikTok videos and 6.5 million Instagram posts are tagged #pressonnails, reflecting a shift towards more cost-effective beauty options amid the cost of living crisis.

Many Aussies have been forced to cut back on luxuries like gel or acrylic manicures to prioritise essentials, making press-ons a popular alternative.

"It's the cost-saving element, but also the time-saving element," Maddy said.

﻿Candy Claws' biggest customer groups are Aussie mums who don't have the time or money to get a manicure and pensioners who can no longer afford trips to the salon.

And with the cost of living crisis showing no signs of easing, it looks like Candy Claws' business will be booming for some time to come.﻿

Have you got a story? Contact reporter Maddison Leach at mleach@nine.com.au

title: Drop in WA Gouldian finch sightings sparks concern
text:
The number of endangered Gouldian finches at a critical site in the far north of Western Australia has halved in the past year, according to a new population count.

Conservation charity Save the Gouldian Fund has just completed its annual survey of the colourful birds in Wyndham — home to the largest known population of the species — located about 3,300 kilometres north-east of Perth in the East Kimberley.

Once among the most common finches found across northern Australia, Gouldian numbers have plummeted over the past century, from hundreds of thousands to an estimated 2,500 in the wild.

Gouldian finch numbers appear to be declining in the Wyndham region. (Supplied: Kacie Austin)

Save the Gouldian Fund chief executive Gary Fitt said the population in Wyndham had been steadily falling.

"In 2023, we were counting on average about 1,700 Gouldians a day," Dr Fitt said.

"The following year, it dropped to 1,500.

"Last year was 1,200, and this year, under 500."

Lack of rainfall causes decline

Dr Fitt attributed the sharp decline to poor wet season rainfall earlier in 2025, which likely stunted the growth of native sorghum, a key food source for the birds.

He also raised concerns about frequent burning around Wyndham, which could destroy nesting habitat and force the birds to travel further in search of food.

"The level of fires and level of burning around Wyndham is really concerning," he said.

Gouldian numbers have plummeted over the past century. (Supplied: Bruce Doran)

"Because that means the birds have to move around a lot more to find what remaining food there is."

Despite the drop, Dr Fitt remained optimistic.

"I think if there's a good wet season next year and there's plenty of sorghum, the numbers may well come back up," he said.

"The numbers that we're seeing now are still well above what we were seeing back in the late 1990s, as the population was declining to the point where the bird was declared endangered."

WA government under investigation

The low numbers in Wyndham come as the federal government investigates whether the WA government has breached environmental conditions tied to protecting Gouldian finches in the nearby Ord Valley.

The WA Department of Primary Industries and Regional Development (DPIRD) is behind the Weaber Plain Development Project, also known as the Goomig Project — a large-scale irrigation scheme involving the clearing of nearly 10,000 hectares of land.

The WA government is under federal investigation over conservation zones in the Ord Valley. (ABC Kimberley: Alys Marshall)

When the project was approved in 2011, the federal government imposed strict environmental conditions, including an 11,545-hectare buffer zone and installation of artificial nest boxes to support Gouldian finches.

But in the past five years, surveys have found no evidence the endangered birds were using the nest boxes within the protected area.

Australian Conservation Foundation national nature campaigner Jess Abrahams said the WA government was failing to meet its obligations.

"We are seeing Gouldian finches disappear from parts of the landscape that are no longer suitable to support them, and that's a real tragedy," he said.

"If governments continue to approve the destruction of their habitat, continue to fail to act on climate change, if agricultural production continues to encroach on its habitat, I do fear that Gouldian finches will be a thing of the past in this part of Australia."

DPIRD said it recorded Gouldian finch activity in the environmental buffer zone in 2025 through acoustic monitoring trials, which detected juvenile and adult Gouldian finch calls throughout the day, and visual surveys.

"Despite the demonstrated presence of Gouldian finches in the general area, the artificial nesting boxes installed to satisfy Weaber Plain development requirements remain unoccupied," a spokesperson said.

"Survey and trial results will form part of DPIRD's federal compliance reporting obligations for the Weaber Plain development."

The federal Department of Climate Change, Energy, the Environment and Water has not yet released the findings of its investigation.

A spokesperson said it would be inappropriate to comment while the process was ongoing.

title: All Blacks preparing for 'real discomfort' after record loss to Springboks
text:
New Zealand captain Scott Barrett has called on the All Blacks players to use the "discomfort" of their record 43-10 defeat to South Africa as fuel to rebound ahead of their next Rugby Championship clash against Australia.

A week after beating the Springboks 24-17 at Auckland's Eden Park, the All Blacks crashed to their worst Test loss on Saturday night as the visitors piled on 36 unanswered points in Wellington.

Lock Barrett, part of a forward pack that was well beaten on the night, said the sting of the defeat would not fade quickly over the two weeks before meeting the Wallabies at Eden Park.

"There'll be some real discomfort this week," he told reporters.

"But I'm sure this team will use that to bounce forward. We've got the Bledisloe [Cup] ahead and a chance to respond."

The All Blacks' final two Tests of the Rugby Championship double as the Bledisloe Cup, the annual trans-Tasman series contested with Australia.

Wallabies go down to Pumas despite fightback Photo shows A Wallabies rugby union player grimaces as he is wedged between two Pumas players in a tackle. The Wallabies fall just short of a magical comeback against Argentina, losing 28-26 in a thrilling Rugby Championship Test in Sydney.

After the Auckland encounter on September 27, the two sides meet again in Perth on October 4.

The Wallabies, who were beaten 28-26 by Argentina in Sydney on Saturday, lead the Rugby Championship with 11 points, one ahead of second-placed South Africa and New Zealand.

Having beaten South Africa with a smart aerial game at Eden Park, All Blacks coach Scott Robertson said his team failed to deal with their high balls in Wellington during the six-tries-to-one rout.

"When they [Springboks] got rolling, they were relentless. We couldn't buy a moment, and they punished us," Robertson said.

"They've been criticised for it in the past, but they own that space now. They put pressure on us, and it worked."

While declining to blame his players, Robertson said the entire squad needed to take responsibility for the setback before they could move forward.

"Firstly, [we need to] own it," he said.

"Get some responsibility and find out what we need to fix.

"We're not going to be chasing too many things. We've got to be clear about what matters most to us on and off the field.

"Then, get a plan and look forward to this next game."

Reuters

title: How to watch the 77th primetime Emmys
text:
US television's night of nights is fast approaching and Apple TV+ show Severence is the stand-out, with 27 nominations, including for Best Drama.

The 77th Annual Primetime Emmys will broadcast live from Los Angeles's Peacock Theater, with winners chosen by 26,000 performers, directors, producers and other members of the Television Academy.

Here's when they're on and how to watch.

When are the 2025 Primetime Emmys?

The Primetime Emmys will take place on the evening of September 14 in LA, which is 10am AEST on September 15 in Australia.

If you're interested in the frocks, the red carpet pre-show will kick off about 9am AEST.

Where can I watch the 2025 Primetime Emmys?

If you have Foxtel, you can watch it on the Arena channel.

You can also stream it on Binge.

There will also be a live blog of the ceremony on the ABC News website.

Who will host the 2025 Primetime Emmys?

For the first time, American comedian Nate Bargatze will host the Emmys this year.

He has hosted Saturday Night Live twice and won a Grammy for best comedy album.

Who will present?

Sydney Sweeney and Stephen Colbert are among some of the famous faces tapped to present at this year's Emmys.

Other actors announced as presenters include:

Elizabeth Banks

Ike Barinholtz

Angela Bassett

Jason Bateman

Kathy Bates

Kristen Bell

Sterling K Brown

Jennifer Coolidge

Alan Cumming

Eric Dane

Colman Domingo

Tina Fey

Walton Goggins

Tony Goldwyn

Kathryn Hahn

Mariska Hargitay

Justin Hartley

Charlie Hunnam

Jude Law

Are there other Emmys?

Yes, there are several other Emmy award ceremonies that recognise different sectors of the television industry and take place at different times.

As well as the Primetime Emmys there are, Daytime, Sports, News & Documentary, and International Emmys, in addition to various Regional Emmy Awards.

The Creative Arts Emmys, which celebrate technical and artistic achievements in prime-time television, also took place this week.

They generally honour behind-the-scenes crews the week before stars of the same shows take to the stage for the prime-time ceremony.

Who is nominated for the Primetime Emmys?

You can see the full list of Primetime Emmy nominations here.

title: Australia's press gallery has a unique problem with its political coverage
text:
Last week's Media Watch raised some fascinating questions about political reporting in Canberra.

In one segment, host Linton Besser talked about the culture of "drops".

A "drop" is when a political reporter is given a story under embargo, which means the story can't be published before a certain time.

But a norm has existed for decades, for a particular kind of drop, that finds journalists agreeing to run a story, given to them by a government or opposition MP, on the proviso that they don't include any quotes from third parties in the first version of their story.

If you didn't see the Media Watch segment, it's worth watching.

See the segment below.

It suggests that the culture of strings-attached drops has become more blatant in Canberra in recent years.

Loading...

Is it time for the practice to end, as Besser suggested?

Because if we want it to end, the press gallery will have to overcome its collective action problem.

A glutton for punishment

A quick anecdote.

One of the most memorably abusive phone calls I've received in my time in Canberra came from a staffer in then-prime minister Malcolm Turnbull's office.

That staffer was an ex-journalist.

I was working at Guardian Australia at the time, in 2018, when Turnbull decided to announce his plan to turn Australia into one of the world's top 10 weapons exporters.

Australia's Future Fund invests in the global arms industry Photo shows Loyal Wingman plane in flight Would the Future Fund's financial returns suffer if it stopped investing in the global arms industry?

I was working the Sunday shift that day, as a political reporter, so I was sent the "drop" to write up the story for online.

The story was embargoed until 8pm that evening (if I recall), which meant lots of news outlets would be publishing the story that evening.

The long-established "norm" for that kind of drop was that, when you wrote the story up, you couldn't include comments from opposition MPs or other third parties in your initial article, because it was a major policy announcement from the government.

But there was no rule that said you couldn't provide political context in the story.

So, when I wrote the story up, I included this context in my article:

The controversial plan has been anticipated since mid-2017 when Christopher Pyne, the defence industry minister, said he wanted to start selling far more Australian-made weapons overseas. At the time, Tim Costello, the World Vision Australia chief advocate, attacked the plan, saying the government had cut humanitarian aid which saved lives while simultaneously discussing the merits of becoming a major weapons manufacturer and exporter. "The government says this is an export and investment opportunity, but we would be exporting death and profiting from bloodshed," Costello said last year. "There is only one purpose in making a weapon and that is to kill someone with it. Do we really want that to be what people think of when they see the brand 'made in Australia'?" Costello said at the time that the contemporary Syrian war — now in its eighth year — could not have lasted for more than a year without armaments profiteering. As a result, there had been more than 300,000 people killed, including thousands of children, 13.5 million people in need of humanitarian assistance, 6.3 million people internally displaced and 5 million people turned into refugees.

I filed the story and went home.

The initial headline on the story included the phrase "exporting death" or "profiting from bloodshed" (I can't remember which), which was a reference to the criticism that Tim Costello had made of the idea six months earlier, to which I'd alerted readers.

And an hour or so after the story went live that night, I was in my kitchen cooking dinner when I got a phone call from Turnbull's staffer.

He was furious. He accused me of breaking the norm for drops.

"What do you mean?" I asked.

He said I'd gone to Tim Costello for a quote.

I tried to explain to him that I hadn't gone to Costello. That quote in my story from Costello was six months old. Costello had made that criticism of the Coalition's policy in July 2017 when the idea was floated by Christopher Pyne.

But he was having none of it. His anger had shut his brain down.

"You're a f***ing disgrace," he seethed.

"You're a s*** journalist. You're pathetic. This is journalism 101. You don't deserve to be in the gallery. You're not good enough."

On and on it went. A stream of personal abuse.

A collective action problem

Now, generally speaking, it hasn't been my experience that editors care that much if their journalists get verbally abused by staffers or politicians, unless the abuse is turned up to 11.

They're too busy with other things. We're all adults. And what could they do about it anyway?

Labor to water down transparency laws, allow blanket FOI refusals Photo shows Albanese water The government will argue the "proper functioning" of government is hampered by disclosure laws and push for wide-ranging restrictions on the information that can be released to the public.

But there's not enough recognition from editors that journalists in the press gallery are trapped in a toxic dynamic when they're expected to keep staffers and MPs on side, regardless of how they're treated, so they don't miss any "drops" on big policy announcements.

It's a gross situation to be put in, and it creates an intolerable power imbalance in the staffer's favour.

Why do some daily news editors care so much about drops?

Because they hate waking up in the morning to discover that a rival news outlet has a big story on a major policy announcement and their own outlet doesn't have the same story.

Why don't they just refuse to take drops that come with strings attached?

Because if one news outlet in the press gallery is willing to accept such drops, other news outlets feel pressure to accept such drops too.

The fear is that, if your news outlet never accepted drops with strings attached, your rival (which had no qualms about it) would look like the agenda-setting news outlet that always had the big policy announcements, and you'd always look like you were chasing your rival's coverage.

For the press gallery, it's a collective action problem.

The gallery has the power to kill the culture of strings-attached drops in Parliament House. If every news outlet in the hallway believed it was in their collective interest to do so, and they acted as one, they could kill the practice tomorrow.

But who expects that to happen?

The temptation for one news outlet to break away from any gallery pact, to get the "scoop" on their rivals with a juicy drop that kicked off the next major news cycle, would be too great.

And once that happened once, other outlets would go back to receiving strings-attached drops again.

There's a solution

How does the press gallery break out of that logic?

In last week's Media Watch, the segment included a quote from the Sydney Morning Herald's Peter Hartcher.

Mr Hartcher said when reporters received a drop from an MP's office, they should simply ignore any demand that the initial write-up of the drop can't include quotes from third parties.

"Reporters should ignore this unethical constraint and remember that their main responsibility is to their readers, viewers and listeners, not their sources," he said.

But Hartcher should know that that's not how the world works.

As the media works to win trust, people say they want the truth Photo shows A graphic showing someone looking at their phone with social media icons around their head. Australians want journalists to tell the truth. Is that a simple request?

Lowly ranked individual journalists in major newsrooms can't just refuse to do that, if they want to keep their job.

They'd need to know that their editors backed them first.

And that would require editors announcing to their newsrooms that no more stories will be published based on drops, if the drops come with certain demands from an MP's office.

Sometimes you'll see an editor trying to improve the quality of their political coverage by telling their political reporters that they won't be publishing any more stories that include quotes from anonymous sources.

They could issue a similar diktat for drops, if they wanted to.

And if they did that, they might be surprised to see how quickly it would rebalance the power dynamic between their journalists and the MPs and staffers their journalists have to deal with.

In one move, it would create a slightly better working environment for their journalists in Canberra, and it would strip some power from arrogant MPs and staffers who consider it their right to have some news framed in certain ways by controlling the flow of information through the press gallery with divide-and-conquer tactics.

Editors could even use that editorial policy to their market advantage by loudly publicising the fact that their news outlet doesn't accept strings-attached drops, but their rivals do.

If they don't respect the way their rivals "do news," why would they want to mimic them anyway?

And if morning TV and radio hosts felt the need to follow a drop-based story from a rival news outlet one morning, they could tell their listeners that the story was clearly a drop, and that's why they're interrogating it now.

Who cares if a "norm" has existed for decades?

If we think the press gallery should still exist as an institution, there's no reason why a few practices shouldn't be overhauled for the 21st century.

title: Outback nurse tackles diabetes with cans, rocks, bush tucker and chat
text:
When Rishoniy Caine arrived in a tiny outback NSW town with one general store, no gym and the task of fixing its diabetes problem, she decided to do things a differently.

The Bundjalung woman knew from her experience as a nurse in remote Kimberly and Cape York communities the difficulties residents faced buying healthy food.

"If you can imagine the nearest town is 1,000 kilometres away, it can be very challenging to get fresh food. It's almost non-existent," she said.

" Also a lettuce might be $16 and two litres of milk $12, while a can of coke is $2, a pie is cheap. "

She incorporated what she learnt from elders about bush foods and traditional medicine into a pilot program in a rural NSW town that faces similar issues — Collarenebri, about 75 kilometres from Walgett in the state's north-west.

Rishoniy Caine knows the challenges of healthy living in remote communities. (ABC Western Plains: Zaarkacha Marlan)

Cooking and gardening lessons are provided alongside medical treatment and, instead of weights, participants are encouraged to lift cans.

"Many of my patients are told to stop eating the foods they know and take tablets, but they're not given the tools or support to make long-term change," Ms Kaine said.

"I wanted to educate people on why this is so important and then I needed to actually walk alongside them and support them with how to look after their own health long-term."

Tailoring treatment to limited resources

The Healthy Communities Foundation program includes group and one-on-one sessions, in-home cooking visits, mental health support, nutrition education and culturally safe conversations about type 2 diabetes care and prevention.

According to the Rural Doctors' Network, 6.1 per cent of people in western and far western NSW live with type 2 diabetes, higher than the national average of 5.5 per cent.

Western NSW residents are also 40 per cent more likely to die from diabetes-related causes compared to the rest of the state.

Some of the 29 participants in the program told Ms Caine they struggled to follow dietary advice from a specialist who visited town every three months, and healthy food was often unaffordable or unavailable locally.

Instead, the program promotes traditional foods like kangaroo, fish and native greens, and encourages growing or sharing food locally.

Riverside Collarenebri might not have a gym or specialist health services, but there are healthy options. (ABC Western Plains: Zaarkacha Marlan)

Exercise is reframed as everyday movement — not gym workouts or costly routines — but simple tasks like cleaning the house or walking around town.

"In Collarenebri, we don't have a gym, but we do have a beautiful river and a small community that's safe to walk around," Ms Caine said.

"I'm not asking people to buy expensive weights, I'm asking them to get that can of food out of your cupboard and use that."

Community part of the cure

One of Collarenebri's approximately 600 residents, Kellie Henderson discovered she had diabetes in a consultation with Ms Caine 12 months ago.

"It came as a great big shock," she said.

Since joining the program, the 44-year-old has lost almost 30 kilograms, reduced her blood sugar to near-normal levels and reshaped her daily habits.

Rishoniy Caine says people can exercise with whatever they have on hand, like canned food or even rocks. (ABC Western Plains: Zaarkacha Marlan)

"I find things fun — just going for a walk, time to myself, experimenting with different foods," she said.

" If something's worrying me, I'll just ask Rishoniy and she'll explain the good and the bad of it. She's been honest and has explained things to me in a way that I could actually understand. "

Rishoniy Caine shows Kellie Henderson how to prepare a diabetes-friendly meal. (ABC Western Plains: Zaarkacha Marlan)

Ms Henderson said she still had "ups and downs" but felt better supported than in the past.

"I'm determined not to go back to where I was," she said.

"I'm feeling a lot happier."

A model for other communities

Ms Caine said restoring cultural and community connection was as important as managing physical health.

"If you don't look after your body, your mind is not well, and if you don't look after your mind then your spirituality and connection to your community and your culture is not well either," she said.

Early results from the pilot program show improvements in weight, blood sugar levels, mood and social connection.

Herbs, vegetables and bush tucker are affordable options in remote communities. (ABC Western Plains: Zaarkacha Marlan)

"People are becoming healthier, they're losing weight, they're happier, their mental health has improved," Ms Caine said.

" People are starting to share what they grow in their gardens. Communities are coming together and they're starting to teach children and other people in the community. It's become a real community approach. "

Ms Caine presented the model at the Australian Primary Health Care Nurses Association's national conference in July, and believes it could be a blueprint for other communities across Australia.

"You could use this for any chronic disease or for health promotion to keep people well and educate people in holistic wellness before they become unwell," she said.

Final results from the pilot program are expected in November.

title: Wombat makes home in main street bowls club amid habitat loss
text:
A wombat has made its home in the main street of Robe, evidence of an influx of the animals in the South Australian coastal town.

Their numbers appear to be increasing in Robe, as more land in the area is taken up by housing.

Last week, a wombat burrow was discovered leading from Mundy Terrace under a rock retaining wall at the Robe Bowling Club.

The wombat burrow that has appeared under the Robe Bowling Club on Robe's main street. (Supplied: District Council of Robe)

District Council of Robe chief executive Nat Traeger said the situation was not yet like the movie Caddyshack, in which a gopher messes with a greenskeeper by digging holes all over a golf course.

"It doesn't really look like it's going to pop out, but we did certainly have a chat with the bowling club just in case they were fearful that it might pop up under their bowling green and do damage there, but they're not too worried about it," she said.

" We certainly don't wish the little fella harm, but we certainly don't want to see it damage our infrastructure as well. "

Wombats at the Robe Golf Club in March 2024 (left) and March 2021 (right). (Supplied: Robe Golf Club)

More wombats on roads

Southern hairy-nosed wombats populate the state's Murraylands and far west, but in the South East, common or bare-nosed wombats are becoming more abundant.

Ms Traeger said Robe had good habitat for wombats but, sadly, more were dying on roads after they were hit by cars.

"If the population gets to a point, it's probably not surprising that they do spill into Robe streets," she said.

"You see seals in our marina and you see kangaroos and wallabies hopping through the main street."

Wombats are regularly seen on greens at the Robe Golf Club, which is surrounded on two sides by houses, another by bushland and a third by coastal dunes.

A burrow recently appeared in a sand bunker on the 11th hole.

A wombat burrow in the sand bunker on the 11th hole at the Robe Golf Club. (Supplied: Robe Golf Club)

But club president Luke Whitbread, who also has about seven or eight living on his rural block, said he was not worried.

"They've been around forever and a day," he said.

Possible habitat to be cleared

In 2023, a judge upheld a decision by the Robe council to knock back a development on the southern edge of the town, saying it was "likely" the land was a "significant" habitat for wombats, although the Native Vegetation Council said they appeared to have abandoned it.

More recently, the Environment, Resources and Development Court has directed the council to approve the land to be cleared for 18 new housing blocks.

An abandoned wombat burrow seen on the subdivision site in Robe. (Supplied: Native Vegetation Council)

After previously advising the council to refuse the subdivision, the Native Vegetation Council approved the land clearing after the developer reached an agreement with the Robe Golf Club to protect 40 hectares of coastal dune vegetation in exchange for 1.5 hectares of land to be razed for housing.

"We have approval to clear the entire block — it only took three years and $550,000," one of the men behind the development, Warren Tucker, said.

Co-existence possible

Wombats SA owns 29 hectares of land just east of the main part of Robe, known as Cullen Reserve.

Volunteers recently visited to remove weeds on the property.

Vice-president Peter Clements said the animals appeared to be doing "quite well", with lots of droppings at the site.

However, he said some of their habitat had been taken up by housing over the past two years.

"There is a new housing development where there would have been a lot of wombat habitat, so they may have to go elsewhere and they're looking around for places and bowling greens might be very tempting," he said.

A wombat at Long Gully campground in Little Dip Conservation Park, near Robe. (Supplied: Rob Brooks)

Luckily for wombats, though, Dr Clements said home owners were "delighted" to see them and friendly towards them, even if they left holes and cube-shaped faeces.

"It's a bit of a difficult balance, but as long as people are aware of them and not destroying them or willingly destroying their habitat, it should work," he said.

title: Steeplechaser stops to help struggling rival at World Athletics Champs
text:
As his heat of the men's 3,000 metres steeplechase neared its conclusion at the World Athletics Championships in Tokyo, Tim Van de Velde looked back over his shoulder.

What he saw was a fellow competitor gingerly crawling over the last barrier that went terribly wrong for both.

Van de Velde's hopes of qualifying for the final were already crushed.

The Belgian turned around, put an arm around stumbling Carlos San Martin and helped the Colombian limp to the finish line.

Tim Van de Velde (right) fell at a water jump during his heat in Tokyo. (Reuters: Eloisa Lopez)

The show of sportsmanship on Saturday evening between the 10th and 11th-place finishers came in an otherwise routine heat.

But it was a highlight of a busy opening night at the World Athletics Championships, even on a day when five gold medals were handed out.

"I saw him stumbling and thought, 'Why not?'" Van de Velde said after the race.

"We both had bad luck, I guess. Maybe we can share some bad luck together."

Earlier, Van de Velde was racing at the front of the leading pack as they approached the water pit in the third lap of the heat.

Steeplechasers are required to vault five three-foot-high barriers placed around the track, one of which fronts the two-foot-deep water obstacle.

He clipped the barrier and fell in the water, and by the time he got up, his hopes were dashed.

Van de Velde raced the rest of the way just to say he finished.

The 25-year-old is no stranger to these sorts of slip-ups.

He broke his collarbone after a fall at the European Championships in Rome last year.

At the 2022 World Athletics Championships in Eugene, he fell into the water and injured his ankle.

"I know what it's like to feel helpless on the track," Van de Velde said.

Carlos San Martin needed assistance as he left the track. (Getty Images: Hannah Peters)

As does San Martin, who was helped off the track in a wheelchair and did not come through the media's mixed zone.

Van de Velde said it would take time to recover from his latest disappointment.

The positive news is there is a great chance he will be remembered for something other than where he finished.

"We're both competitors. We both work very hard," Van de Velde said.

"Of course, the main goal was the final and we both had bad luck, so that's why I did it."

AP

title: Appeasing the hungry ghosts of Christmas Island's painful past
text:
Twilight on Christmas Island, about 2,600 kilometres north-west of Perth, grows heavy with the memory of lost souls.

"We know that at least 300, maybe more than 400 Chinese people especially, died in the first 10 years of settlement," acting shire chief executive Chris Su says.

"They were worked to death, essentially, by the regime of the day.

"We believe that they come back this month every year, so we should make offerings for them and thank them for their contribution to establishing life on Christmas."

The seventh month of the Chinese lunar calendar is known as "hungry ghosts month" to Christmas Island residents.

Each Saturday over four weeks, they congregate at one of several Taoist and Buddhist temples scattered across the remote Indian Ocean territory.

Candles are lit and offerings burnt to appease passed ancestors. (ABC Pilbara: Mietta Adams)

Chinese communities around Australia and the world mark the festival, but Christmas Island's event pays special homage to its distinct history.

Chris Su was born in Singapore amid ongoing medical restrictions that bar island births.

Brought to Christmas Island as an infant, he has observed the ancient tradition all his life.

Chris Su has taken part in the ceremony since he was a child. (ABC Pilbara: Mietta Adams)

"These [ghosts] are people who have died far from home," Mr Su says.

"They didn't get a proper burial, they didn't have any descendants to make them offerings

" We believe they are hungry, of sorts, in the afterworld. "

The festivities are to appease the "hungry ghosts" on the island. (ABC Pilbara: Mietta Adams)

Offerings in flames

About 100 people meet at a small temple in Drumsite, near a dusty industrial area that still houses the remnants of an incline railway.

Loading...

In the early 1900s, small hopper cars carried precious mounds of phosphate through the neighbourhood, moving steeply from jungle quarries to port.

Mr Su explains that the temple, tucked away on a now-suburban street, is dedicated to the deity Sheng Wong.

"He [Sheng Wong] and his two marshals on the left and right of him open the gates of the underworld and let the hungry ghosts pass through to walk the material world to take offerings," Mr Su said.

Honouring Sheng Wong, deity of the underworld. (ABC Pilbara: Mietta Adams)

The former phosphate transport hub is a fitting place for the community to gather.

The precious mineral, often used in fertilisers, was in high demand in the 19th century, leading to the recruitment of hundreds of indentured workers, or "coolies", from China to Christmas Island.

Under the Christmas Island Phosphate Company, they were forced to dig four-to-seven tonnes per man each day, often with their bare hands.

Money and incense wrappers are offered to the island's "hungry ghosts". (ABC Pilbara: Mietta Adams)

In 1901, an outbreak of beri-beri killed more than half the labourers, who subsisted almost entirely on white rice.

"Beri-beri … is a type of deficiency disease, not having enough nutrition, a very painful way to die," Mr Su says.

" It was very, very hard yards working for the British Empire back in the day and for a pittance. "

Offerings to the restless spirits go up in flames. (ABC Pilbara: Mietta Adams)

Worshippers lay out tables of food and burn paper money in a large bonfire, with hopes the offerings will ease the ghosts' hunger.

But it is not just the "coolies" Christmas Island residents remember.

Fifteen children were among 50 Iraqi and Iranian asylum seekers who drowned off Christmas Island when their vessel crashed into its rocky cliffs in 2010.

The ceremony takes place in the seventh month of the Chinese lunar calendar. (ABC Pilbara: Mietta Adams )

It was a brutal chapter for an island so closely associated with its immigration detention centre.

The controversial facility spent decades at the centre of Australia's boat turnbacks policy and was being briefly mothballed in 2018, before it was reopened for pandemic quarantine.

It remains in a limbo-like "hot contingency" state to this day.

In the aftermath of the 2010 disaster, residents offered a paper boat (bottom), baby shoes, and formula for those who lost their lives. (Supplied: Chris Su)

"You will see baby formula and baby food and baby shoes at the offering ceremony sites, because baby spirits can't eat adult food," Mr Su says.

" We make formula; we offer it to them. "

Community around the table

Foo Kee Heng, a community elder and committee president of the Drumsite temple, sits at a corner table as people shuffle through, lighting candles and offering prayers.

Foo Kee Heng says offering the ghosts food and money will give people peace. (ABC Pilbara: Mietta Adams)

He says the ceremony brings peace to the living and the dead.

"The celebration of this ghost festival, [we] offer them the money, the food and they will give you peace too," he says.

"That's what all this festival is about."

Islanders of different backgrounds and generations come together to mark the festival. (ABC Pilbara: Mietta Adams)

Attendees are invited to share in a traditional feast — no small feat on an island where a head of lettuce can cost upwards of $16.

Food offerings are an important part of the ceremony for the "hungry ghosts". (ABC Pilbara: Mietta Adams)

Powerful superstitions

During the month-long festival, Mr Su warns the scent of frangipanis should be avoided.

"If you're walking around at night time and you start to smell a very fragrant smell, especially franjipani, it means the spirits are near," he says.

" Avoid cutting your fingernails at night ... [and] don't hang out too close to banana trees. "

Chinese temples are dotted throughout Christmas Island. (ABC Pilbara: Mietta Adams)

Yet even the superstitions are a respected part of Christmas Island's colourful cultural tapestry.

"Christmas Island has a mix of people from the east and the west and what you find here is something that happens in neither the east nor the west today," Mr Su says.

" People just living pluralistically together ... you share the island and you share it with all the people who aren't exactly like you. "

title: Inaugural Blue hopes for finals berth after hot start
text:
Carlton defender Harriet Cordner said if she was to sum up playing for the Blues right now in one word, it'd be "fun".

If you'd asked her back in January if she expected Carlton to be in the top four come round five, she admittedly probably wouldn't have said yes.

Yet the Blues sit in third spot — with games left to play this round — with a high percentage after claiming their third straight win against Gold Coast on Saturday by 46 points.

"We did all the hard work in the off-season and the pre-season and now Bucky [head coach Mathew Buck] is really leaning into our ability to actually just enjoy what we're doing out there," Cordner told ABC Sport.

"We've added speed with the ball to our game plan and I think you can see that. And so it's fun to play in."

Harriet Cordner joined Carlton for the 2023 season. (Getty: Robert Cianflone)

Carlton made the grand final in 2019, back when the league was in a conference system, yet fell to Adelaide by 45 points at Adelaide Oval in front of 53,034 people.

The Blues looked a chance to make the following decider after qualifying for a preliminary final the next year, but the 2020 season was cancelled during finals due to COVID.

Having not made finals since, the club then attempted to navigate somewhat of a rebuild while the competition went through expansions in 2020 and 2022.

They lost significant players to expansion teams, including league best and fairest Maddy Prespakis and goal sneak Georgia Gee to Essendon, Lucy McEvoy to Sydney and Grace Egan to Richmond.

Just Darcy Vescio, Pound and Breann Moody remain from the 2017 side.

Last year the Blues finished 14th on the ladder and 12th the year before that.

Saturday's win was the first time they have won three consecutive games since 2022, which included a shock upset victory against the reigning grand finalists Brisbane in round three.

Carlton kicked seven goals to nothing in the second half to run away from Gold Coast. (Getty: Robert Cianflone)

Sidelined inaugural Blue Gab Pound said it felt like the club was turning a corner this year. Something that has been exciting to watch, if not difficult having to watch on given her shin injury.

"It really feels like we're [in] a little turning point here," Pound told ABC Sport.

"There isn't many in our team from that 2019 grand final … But I'm really hoping that we can play some really continuous and good football and hopefully have some sort of finals berth year.

"Early wins at the start of the season are so important for everything, for not only the points, but also the belief coming into the rest of the season."

Part of the change at Carlton has been the few added list pieces, including former Suns captain Tara Bohanna, and the young talent coming through in Sophie McKay (three goals against Gold Coast), Poppy Schloz and Lila Keck.

"The depth that we're running on the entire list is something that's really exciting," said Pound, who is expected to be available for selection come round seven or eight.

"I know when I'm going to try and get back into the side, it's going to be really hard, but that's something that we really want."

In his third year as Carlton head coach, Mathew Buck has seen the Blues start 4-1. (Getty: Michael Willson/AFL Photos)

In the third year under Buck, Cordner said the Blues have wanted to move the ball quickly.

"We've added speed with the ball to our game plan, and I think you can see that," Cordner said.

Pound agreed, and said there'd been a focus on "really brave and exciting" footy.

"We really recognised that our fundamentals were something that we really wanted to work on," Pound said.

"Bucky, he's changing a few things and adapting for us, and it's really working."

That game plan will be properly challenged next week as Carlton front up against the reigning premiers and undefeated North Melbourne at Arden Street Oval before facing Fremantle back at their home in Princes Park.

title: 'White-hot anger' in the bush as Victorians take on Allan government
text:
Yellow has become the colour of discontent and defiance in rural Victoria.

Bright yellow volunteer firefighter overalls are draped on fence lines and outside country fire stations in protest at the Emergency Services and Volunteer Fund announced in the May state budget.

Formerly known as the Services Property Levy, the Victorian government says the increased tax will provide a broader range of disaster response services.

CFA volunteers have been hanging up their uniforms in protest at the Emergency Services and Volunteers Fund. (ABC Rural: Warwick Long)

"We stand ready with well-resourced emergency services to help those communities in the event of a natural disaster," Victorian Treasurer Jaclyn Symes told Landline.

But many country people, like western Victorian farmer and Country Fire Authority volunteer Pat Millear, are not buying that explanation.

A message for Premier Jacinta Allan at a bakery in Willaura, western Victoria. (Landline: Tim Lee)

"It's an absolute kick in the guts for them [volunteer firefighters] to be told that they're going to have to pay into an emergency services volunteer fund," Mr Millear said.

" All they're doing is just putting money in their big black hole in Melbourne. "

Pat Millear says the fund is a "kick in the guts" for volunteer firefighters. (Landline: Tim Lee)

Mr Millear has publicly opposed the levy at protest rallies, including one outside Parliament House in Melbourne, when farmers filled city streets with tractors.

Further rallies about a range of grievances are planned for regional centres.

Ms Symes defended the new volunteer levy and said all Victorians must pay it as part of their local government rates.

This year, they will rise by an average of 29 per cent for residential property owners and about 63 per cent for commercial and industrial properties.

Primary producers have been granted a temporary pause on increases this financial year, but the variable rate for them will increase significantly after that.

An effigy dressed in Country Fire Authority overalls, part of a protest at Gre Gre, north-west Victoria. (Landline: Tim Lee)

Its representative body, Rural Councils Victoria (RCV), sought legal advice on how to avoid collecting the levy for the state government, but found councils were compelled to do so.

Rural Victoria rates notices now include disclaimers explaining the increase is due to the state government levy.

Corangamite Mayor Kate Makin, the RCV's South West Region representative, warns that if residents refuse to pay their rates, councils will have to use their own finances to pay the levy.

Kate Makin says rural councils are also unhappy about the state of roads. (Landline: Tim Lee)

The levy is just one RCV grievance.

"We've got multiple taxes, we've got housing shortages, childcare shortages, workforce shortages and, of course, our roads," Cr Makin said.

Emergency services levy anger Photo shows Firefighters walk between a row of emergency vehicles. The backlash against Victoria's emergency services levy is intensifying and some councils fear refusal to pay will generate a revenue shortfall.

"I would say most are undriveable and we are sick of not being able to make this infrastructure and make our communities better going forward.

Ms Symes said she was well aware of the challenge of poor roads.

"Roads is probably the issue that I hear about the most," she said.

Potholes at Timboon, south-west Victoria. (Landline: Tim Lee)

"We are spending almost $1 billion on maintenance. That is something that we're very much focused on as a government."

Renewable energy infrastructure is also highly contentious.

Sheep and crop producer Jason Barratt, of Gre Gre, in Victoria's north-west, said he and others who own property in the path of massive high-voltage transmission lines would willingly risk heavy fines to halt the proposed work.

Jason Barratt says he is prepared to risk heavy fines to stop transmission lines on his Gre Gre property. (ABC: Kyle Harley)

"We don't want these transmission towers, these 280-metre tall wind turbines, batteries, solar panels. We just don't want that out here," Mr Barratt said.

"We don't want this environment destroyed."

Protest signs opposing power transmission lines at Gre Gre, in the Northern Grampians. (Landline: Tim Lee)

The treasurer conceded building renewable power infrastructure on private farm land could have been handled better in the past.

But she defended her government's recently passed legislation that imposes heavy fines on people who obstruct power infrastructure as in line with other jurisdictions.

Katherine Myers, a potato farmer and vice-president of the Victoria Farmers' Federation, labelled it a heavy-handed escalation in the conflict.

Katherine Myers says there is anger over penalties for people who obstruct power infrastructure. (Landline: Tim Lee)

She said people were angry that police could be used to "force access on farms, where farmers don't want that, and that fines will be issued up to $12,000 for an individual and $50,000 for a business".

"It just feels like a punch from the city, saying rural Victoria doesn't matter," Ms Myers said.

Ms Symes said the government wanted to work with farmers and compensation was available if properties were affected.

"That's why we've set up the community benefits fund to ensure that communities can come to government and talk about things that are important to them," she said.

Ms Myers wants the Western Renewables Link, set to be built across her family property, to be installed underground.

But Ms Symes said that option was both too expensive and ineffectual.

Jaclyn Symes lives in regional Victoria and says she understands the issues facing rural residents. (Landline: Tim Lee)

She said she was sympathetic to the challenges facing rural Victorians but believes their discontent is also due to drought, the high cost of living and interest-rate pressures.

But Cr Makin said there were more rural challenges and listed proposed mining projects on agricultural land, regional job cuts to the Agriculture Department, housing shortages and a declining rate base for councils.

"Our communities are really resilient but that resilience is wearing very thin," Cr Makin said.

Farmer outcry over new electricity laws Photo shows A replica transmission tower is burned. Farmers say they will continue to refuse access to transmission line builders, despite the passing of legislation that could see them arrested for doing so.

Mr Barratt said rural Victorians were fed up with feeling neglected by what he described as a city-centric government.

"At the moment in our community there is white-hot anger," he said.

" People are at their wits' end. "

The treasurer said rural Victorians had to be patient and trust her government.

"We are passionate about rural and regional Victoria," she said.

"We're listening to you, we're responding to your needs, we're making tough decisions but we're putting you at the front of those decisions."

Watch ABC TV's Landline at 12:30pm AEST on Sunday or stream anytime on ABC iview.

title: World-famous bee sanctuary under threat from destructive parasite
text:
Shawn Hinves and his family have created an idyllic life for themselves on their Kangaroo Island farm.

From the verandah of their home, they can see their sheep, goats, cows and two pet kangaroos.

Koalas lounge in the trees that they planted 20 years ago.

But at the heart of their existence is one fascinating insect, the Ligurian honey bee.

"It's sort of changed my whole life completely," Shawn Hinves, a former tyre fitter said.

"They've been recognised as the most pure strain of Ligurian bee left in the world.

"I have a great appreciation of what they are, what they do, and everything that they produce has a positive effect on the human body."

Kangaroo Island is home to purest strain of the Italian Ligurian bee. (ABC News: Che Chorley)

The Ligurian bees were brought from Italy to the island, 13.5 kilometres off South Australia's Fleurieu Peninsula, in 1884 and it was declared a sanctuary in 1885. It is said to be the oldest bee sanctuary in the world.

There are now five-to-six commercial beekeepers on the Island that have opened shops and tourism operations, running beekeeping tours and employing more than 50 locals. There are also up to 100 hobby apiarists who keep hives on the island too.

But their bees and the businesses they sustain are now facing perhaps their greatest threat as the Varroa destructor spreads quickly across Australia.

The island's industry is under threat from the deadly Varroa mite that arrived in Australia in 2022. (ABC News: Che Chorley)

The deadly mite was first detected in the Port of Newcastle in NSW, in June 2022 and has since spread to Victoria, Queensland, ACT and two weeks ago, was found in South Australia for the first time.

South Australian Apiarists Association president Brenton Davis said the mite would have a "big impact" and more needed be done to protect Kangaroo Island's bees.

"It's an internationally-significant population and very much needs to be protected," Mr Davis said.

"[Varroa] is one of the most significant pests the Australian beekeeping industry has ever seen, so it's going to have a big impact on the industry.

"We need to do everything we can to in order to stop the Varroa from getting to Kangaroo Island."

Mr Davis says more needs be done to protect Kangaroo Island's bees from Varroa mite. (ABC News: Stephen Opie)

The mite is about the size of sesame seed, but can wipe out hives with thousands of bees.

"It actually drills a hole into the bee and then lives on the bee's fat deposits," Mr Davis said.

"So, opening up the bees to the susceptibility to viruses it weakens them and it can actually kill out colonies quite quickly."

'Ferocious' mite

Attempts to eradicate the mite from Australia were abandoned in September 2023 with the national strategy now aimed at slowing the spread.

But that has proved difficult as bees are regularly transported across state borders to help pollinate different crops, including almonds. It was bees brought in from Queensland that led to the Varroa mite reaching SA's Riverland.

The former tyre-fitter turned beekeeper began as a hobbyist before his passion became his vocation. (ABC News: Che Chorley)

Shawn Hinves said greater effort should have been taken to contain the Varroa mite.

"It's very frustrating … if the end game is just to get Australia infected and just deal with it that way, then that's just how they're gonna do it," Mr Hinves said.

"But if they're serious about biosecurity and protecting beekeepers, the food industry, and everything that wraps around it, then they need … to have more regulation, more rules, higher monitoring, but I just don't think that they're putting enough time, enough effort, enough staff into these big issues."

Legislation in South Australia forbids people bringing a number of products to Kangaroo Island. (ABC News: Che Chorley)

Brian Morrison is a retired diver who lives in picturesque Emu Bay and is one of the island's enthusiastic hobby beekeepers.

"They are just a fascinating critter, and the more you learn, the more you find out you don't know anything about them," Mr Morrison said.

Mr Morrison, like most of the island's beekeepers, is worried that there are not enough biosecurity checks being put in place to protect the bees on the island.

"I am very, very concerned that we're it's not being taken seriously by the government," Mr Morrison said.

"The Varroa mite … that thing is ferocious and in … three-to-four years it will just completely wipe out a hive.

"We've got a unique opportunity to protect it, but they're going to have to start looking seriously at beefing up the biosecurity, something similar to the West Australian border, where every vehicle is stopped and searched.

Brian Morrison is one of up to 100 hobby beekeepers who keep hives on Kangaroo Island. (ABC News: Che Chorley)

"At the moment, these guys at the biosecurity do a good job, but they basically just ask you, 'do you have honey?' So, if you're a dishonest person or you're having a problem with language, which we've found that people from overseas are bringing honey in and not realising because they didn't understand the biosecurity officer."

Frontline checks

Primary Industry Minister Clare Scriven defended the South Australian Government's Varroa management strategy but said she did want to boost frontline services.

"No used bee equipment can go to the island, no honey products can go to the island, no hives can go to the island," Ms Scriven said.

"We have our checks at the ferry terminal.

"We're certainly happy to expand that if it is necessary and I've been speaking with my department today about the staffing levels that we have there and they're currently recruiting for extra staff."

Many hives on the island are still recovering following bushfires in 2019/2020. (ABC News: Che Chorley)

The threat of the Varroa mite comes as the island's honey production levels remain low.

The 2019/2020 Kangaroo Island bushfires wiped out many hives on the western end of the island and trees in the area are yet to start producing nectar that the bees collect for honey production.

Bev Nolan's family owns Clifford's Honey Farm, which has three generations working in the business, and employees 14 people.

"There's still a lot of areas that either got wiped out completely or are still in recovery mode," Ms Nolan said.

Bev Nolan says the Ligurian bees have been vital to Kangaroo Island's tourism industry. (ABC News: Che Chorley)

Ms Nolan said her family had upgraded its shop and diversified products to keep it profitable.

"The Ligurian bees are a really big tourist story," Ms Nolan said.

"It's also … important for the world to have a honey bees that are nice and calm and hardworking and isolated from pests and diseases as well."

But as the threat continues to grow, some like Brian Morrison are considering their future in the industry if Varroa mite makes it onto the island.

The bees were brought to Kangaroo Island in 1884. (ABC News: Che Chorley)

"I'll probably end up getting out of beekeeping, I think that's what will happen," Mr Morrison said.

"I'll be devastated, and you know, maybe then I'll start looking and moving somewhere else … that's how I'm feeling already.

"This algal bloom [after the fires] has kind of been like the last straw.

"I do love it here and the people that live here are fantastic and we do have a good life, but [there] just seems to be one thing after the next at the moment."

title: Postecoglou faces 'Tottenham in disguise' jibe in Forest debut
text:
Ange Postecoglou has promised a quick response after a brutal re-introduction to the Premier League, with Nottingham Forest defeated by Arsenal 3-0.

Postecoglou was appointed Nottingham Forest manager on Tuesday following the sacking of Nuno Espírito Santo.

The move came three months after Postecoglou was let go by Tottenham Hotspur.

Given Arsenal's rivalry with Spurs, the Australian was taunted mercilessly by the Gunners' home crowd as he watched his new Forest charges succumb from the sidelines.

They chanted, "Are you Tottenham in disguise", as the goals rolled in for the Gunners.

While admitting the result was a "disappointing" start to life at Forest, Postecoglou insisted there was no time to waste as he looks to get his side firing, starting against Swansea in the Carabao Cup on Thursday AEST.

Ange vows to take Forest back to the top Photo shows Ange Postecoglou claps his hands after a Tottenham win in the Premier League. Nottingham Forest fans have been made a promise by Ange Postecoglou that he'll give his all to help them bring back their glory days.

"This is not a project," Postecoglou told reporters.

"This football club had a strong season last year, they need to be stronger this year, and my job is to get us to where I want us as quickly as possible.

"On Wednesday night [Thursday AEST], we will start seeing principles being embedded. It won't take long and I will not let it take long.

"I will make sure we turn it around because we have an unbelievable opportunity to make an impact this season, and I am not going to let that slip.

"We've got two sessions before that. We've got another couple of sessions before the next Premier League game, so whatever's happened this week, and how disruptive it's been, we can put a line through it and start looking ahead."

Postecoglou said his preparation for the Arsenal match was far from ideal.

"Seven days ago, their world was totally different to what it was today," he said.

"You've got to understand that. Some players were away on international duty. The other players had the whole weekend off. They only got back in on Tuesday."

Postecoglou, who steered Tottenham to Europa League success last season, said he was determined to help Forest achieve success.

"They're all big jobs," he told TNT Sports.

"I haven't taken over an easy one yet but that's why I'm here. I love the challenge and we'll get to where we want to."

AAP

title: Paradise's four-legged guardian retires from pest-hunting role
text:
Paradise's four-legged guardian is hanging up his leash.

For almost a decade Sebbi the springer spaniel has been Lord Howe Island's last line of defence.

As the longest-serving biosecurity dog on the idyllic land mass, he has helped to keep the island untouched and free of contamination for most of his life.

Both he and his son Zuma have been invasive pests' worst enemy in the island's battle to preserve its unique natural environment.

Lord Howe Island is in the Tasman Sea, located 700 kilometres off the coast of Sydney.

Sebbi's pest detection role helped to preserve the island's unique natural environment. (Supplied)

Now, after years of sniffing and scavenging for pests, Sebbi is off to the doggy retirement village — otherwise known as suburban Brisbane with his former handler.

It is a day everyone on the island who loves Sebbi knew was going to come, especially after he took on an "ambassador" role in his later years where he entertained crowds.

As Sebbi's bright white and copper fur faded, he turned his talents to greeting arrivals at the airport, where he could still put that nose to good use.

And it was his keen nose that was vital in playing a mentoring role to the new dogs ready to fill his prior position.

Sebbi is enjoying his retirement in Brisbane. (Supplied)

So what is next for Sebbi? Embracing everything retirement has to offer, including a new sibling.

"He has settled into our home extremely well and is enjoying going on walks and adventures with his new pup-sister, Lacey," his former handler and new owner Saxxon Thompson said.

Sebbi has settled into the Brisbane lifestyle well, his owner said. (Supplied)

It is thanks to Sebbi and his handlers that in 2023 the island was able to report that it had been free of rodents for two years straight.

Considered a living laboratory by the scores of scientists who conduct research on the island, Sebbi was the knight in shining armour for protecting its over 200 endemic native species.

Add to your watchlist Photo shows Mystery Road Origin ABC iview with young detective Jay Swan in the bush. The critically acclaimed Mystery Road: Origin returns as Detective Jay Swan (Mark Coles Smith) and Mary (Tuuli Narkle) uncover dark secrets in a haunted timber town, where the past threatens to tear them apart.

From endangered palms and at risk coral reefs, there is barely a plant on Lord Howe Island that does not have Sebbi to thank.

But the change of scenery on the mainland is not all that bad.

"After years of dedication and hard work, Sebbi's days are now filled with rest, play and endless cuddles on the couch," Mr Thompson said.

title: A $26m unorthodox childcare deal with devastating fallout
text:
The warning lights were flashing for giant childcare operator G8 Education.

It had an unorthodox $26 million deal on the line to sell centres to Genius Education, a venture whose subsequent collapse would strand staff and parents, and whose boss Darren Misquitta would later plead guilty to receiving suspected proceeds of crime unconnected to the child care industry.

Despite G8 knowing about problems, an ABC investigation can reveal how the childcare giant downplayed concerns and maintained it had conducted checks.

Gold Coast-based G8 even passed on information packages detailing Genius's success to key stakeholders. It was replete with pictures of centres refurbished with sandpits, sunshades and climbing equipment, and glowing references from businessmen including Adrian "Lambo Guy" Portelli.

The deal's fallout was devastating.

Darren Misquitta pleaded guilty last month to receiving $120,000 in suspected proceeds of crime unrelated to the childcare industry. (LinkedIn)

"Genius is like this thunderstorm that just came in and wiped us all out within months," said Samantha White, who resigned as assistant director at one Canberra centre.

" G8 is accountable for their actions and how this has affected thousands of children and hundreds of educators. "

G8 is Australia's biggest for-profit operator, running almost 400 centres under brands including Bambino's and Kindy Patch Kids. The ASX-listed company, valued at almost $600 million, is among big corporates in a sector that was, until the early 2000s, more a cottage industry.

A hodgepodge amalgamation of childcare businesses, G8 owned 175 centres by 2012. Its annual report that year featured a giggling infant wearing thick black glasses, with the company crowing operations were going from "strength to strength". It kept growing.

But earnings see-sawed between losses of $189 million in 2020 to profits of $68 million in 2024. Investors savaged shares this year after a former staffer was charged with child abuse.

In 2023, G8 made a deal to offload 31 outlets to Genius. (ABC News: Joel Wilson)

The deal

Back in October 2023, red ink oozed from some underperforming centres, so G8 fashioned an unorthodox solution: offload 31 outlets to another childcare operator, Genius.

Oddly, G8 would pay $26.5 million to Genius.

The logic, G8 said, was trading the centres through to lease end would be more expensive than handing cash to Genius, which would take on associated liabilities.

But the deal immediately raised industry hackles.

The director of Genius entities was Misquitta, now 41.

He boasted the trinkets of entrepreneurialism: the black t-shirt of new-wave chief executives and a trophy property — an acreage residence on Victoria's elite Mornington Peninsula. He had Deakin University law and commerce degrees, and a resume in banking, mining, education and private equity.

Genius director Darren Misquitta looked the part of a modern millionaire. (Supplied)

But harsh headlines about Genius were published before the deal, involving landlords suing over unpaid rent. A key Misquitta family company that largely owned Genius also faced winding up applications.

G8's new chief executive Pejman Okhovat, a retail industry veteran recruited from Big W, reassured stakeholders. He expressed confidence Genius would "provide the ongoing high level of service that the children, families and our team at these centres expect and deserve".

G8's new chief executive Pejman Okhovat reassured stakeholders Genius would provide an ongoing high level of service. (Supplied)

That month, a Genius subsidiary for a Melbourne's Collins Street childcare centre, which boasted an in-house chef, was tipped into court-ordered liquidation, owing $5 million in a lease dispute. The liquidator complained Misquitta had not supplied financial records as required.

Misquitta maintained he would work with the liquidator, and "external noise" would not disrupt the G8 deal.

Landlords and Lambo guy

G8 was in a bind. To offload centres, G8 needed to convince landlords to transfer leases to Genius. But some landlords were wary of Genius.

The ABC has seen information packs from Genius that G8 forwarded to landlords.

They included accounts, in which Misquitta was listed as sole director of companies, showing earnings within Genius entities.

There were also pretty photographs of refurbished centres; a once sad-looking centre with a faux grass play area, for instance, was transformed with a cute garden with a tree and water pump.

Photos showing the refurbishment of Genius centres were included in an information pack to G8 landlords. (Supplied)

The pitch was Genius could revive poorly performing centres.

The package also included letters of recommendation.

One was from Adrian Portelli, the controversial lottery businessman who in 2022 drove up in a yellow Lamborghini to bid $4.5 million on a home for TV show The Block.

Adrian Portelli with a new Lamborghini. (Supplied: Instagram)

In the letter, Mr Portelli wrote his business had already developed childcare centres and "Genius has been an excellent tenant".

Mr Portelli told the ABC the business had an agreement with Genius to lease centres but they ultimately were not tenanted.

"After that letter, [Misquitta's] and Genius' issues surfaced, so we terminated those agreements," he said. "I did not have direct dealings with him."

Adrian Portelli was among those who wrote a letter of recommendation for Genius. (ABC News: Lisa Batty)

Some financial information also concerned landlords. A Genius group balance sheet, for instance, was bolstered by millions of dollars owed by other Misquitta-linked entities.

Landlord Fiona O'Donnell and extended family had three childcare properties with G8 — they transferred one lease to Genius but withheld two more.

"We were not comfortable about the standing of Genius," she told the ABC. "The financial information provided appeared to be smoke and mirrors."

The pledge

The 26-storey Brisbane offices of law firm Allens is the opposite of a childcare centre — the windows reveal a spectacular CBD view, but the meeting room itself is sterile.

It was May 2024, and G8 was holding its annual shareholder meeting. Mr Okhovat, the chief executive — who at centres can wear a company-labelled polo shirt — was dressed in a businessman's tan suit.

G8 admitted the Genius deal was stumbling. Only 17 centres had transferred to Genius — landlords were edgy and regulatory approvals taking time.

Mr Okhovat told media that G8 was "well aware" of landlord lawsuits entangling Genius, and Genius had provided appropriate evidence "for us to go ahead".

Pejman Okhovat told media that G8 was "well aware" of landlord lawsuits entangling Genius. (Supplied: Instagram)

Given children were involved, did G8 have a responsibility to ensure centres going to Genius would be open for the long-term?

"Very clearly and very concisely: Yes, absolutely," he replied. "We exercise our due diligence at the highest level."

That included to ensure "Genius's financial position was at the right level".

Three weeks later, the United Workers Union published a letter, complaining Genius was not paying staff wages on time. A landlord also claimed Genius defaulted on rent after acquiring one ACT centre in February 2024. The landlord evicted Genius within a year.

It goes to questions including whether G8 was blindsided — or simply did not care if centres floundered once off its books.

One source who has worked with Mr Okhovat regarded him as a straight-dealing businessman, who would have been working to secure a deal genuinely assisting stakeholders. G8 also maintained to the ABC it always intended for "a continuity of care and employment for families and team" in the Genius deal.

The opposite happened.

The takeover tragedy

Ms White's G8 facility in Gowrie, on Canberra's southside, was originally called the Blinky Bill early childhood centre, after the cute koala book character.

It was a well-performing centre, Ms White said, and staff fretted after hearing of Genius services potentially lacking resources and wages were not being paid elsewhere.

Samantha White resigned from her role after the Genius takeover. (Supplied)

Worried staff even stocked up on extra supplies such as nappies while G8 remained owner.

After the transfer, wages were late on the first payday. Then long-planned fixes, such as of fencing and sandpits, also stopped, she said.

Ms White fumes at reassurances G8 provided about Genius.

"It was all lies. You know, we had a full team here at the service and you know, we had beautiful families," she said.

Eighteen centres ultimately were signed over; Genius shut 12 between August 2024 and March this year. The Gowrie centre is one of five still trading under administrators WLP Restructuring.

Eighteen centres were signed over and Genius shut 12 between August 2024 and March this year. (ABC News: Joel Wilson)

The administrators' initial investigations are damning. WLP wrote the Genius subsidiary that acquired the G8 centres may have been insolvent upon commencing trading.

"The director [Misquitta], through related companies, continued to withdraw funds from [that subsidiary and another running centres] resulting in insufficient funds being available to meet the payment of employee wages and statutory liabilities," they wrote.

Administrators also uncovered concerns about accounts for the other subsidiary, alleging amendments were made transforming a balance sheet from an insolvent position of $40 million to a positive $50 million.

"We do not consider that the financial accounts provide an accurate reflection of the true nature of the transactions," they wrote.

It's not clear which Genius company received G8's cash (at least one entity is not in administration). G8's accounts indicate up to $10 million went to Genius.

Break-ups and bankrupts

Misquitta is bankrupt and his marriage has broken down, a court heard. The Mornington estate is gone, seized and sold by lenders.

He pleaded guilty last month to receiving $120,000 in suspected proceeds of crime in 2019, drawn from a business loan from a venture not associated with the childcare deal. Attempts to obtain comment from him were unsuccessful.

G8's chief executive Mr Okhovat, whose take home pay last year was $1.5 million, declined to comment to the ABC.

"If you have any more questions you can send them via email," he said briefly. "Thank you. Appreciate it. Bye."

G8 acknowledged people "may be impacted" by Genius's takeover. (ABC News: Lucas Hill)

G8 emailed anodyne statements that did not answer questions, but argued regulators and landlords had consented to Genius deals.

It acknowledged people "may be impacted" by Genius's takeover.

"However, as G8 Education no longer owns or operates these centres, questions regarding their operation following the change of ownership should be addressed to Genius," it said.

Ms O'Donnell, the landlord, also owns G8 shares and questions checks done on Genius.

"The CEO should be accountable for the due diligence performed and explain how the obvious was missed," she said. "The staff, families and children were treated so poorly."

title: Young people want to avoid being seen as 'cringe' but there's a cost
text:
Marshall and his friends Ashton, Chad, Noah and Lucas see cringe-worthy content on social media a lot.

"I'd say it's pretty popular," says Marshall, 18, from Adelaide.

"It's probably the fact that it's stupid, which makes it fun," Noah says.

Even though it can be fun, being cringe in any way is something many young people want to avoid at all costs.

Chad says: "It can be funny sometimes, but just depends on what it is."

Marshall, Ashton, Chad, Noah and Lucas see cringe content on social media. (BTN High: Michelle Wakim)

So, what is cringe?

Why we love (and hate) cringe TV Photo shows Still of Jan sitting on Michael's lap in The Office episode The Dinner Party Could laughing at awkwardness actually help us release some of our own complicated feelings about it?

The Oxford Dictionary defines "cringe" as an inward feeling of acute embarrassment or awkwardness.

It has been a storytelling device used in movies and popular TV shows, such as US sitcom The Office, for a long time.

More recently, it has appeared in advertising and online content, generating engagement by evoking strong emotions while being relatable to audiences.

From fashion to social media posts

However, cringe culture has now taken the word beyond the dictionary definition.

Sometimes it is a compliment, sometimes it is an insult, and working out what makes us cringe in a good or bad way is subjective.

For Henry, 12, dance videos on TikTok and the hit Netflix movie KPop Demon Hunters are cringe.

Ava, 20, has a similar definition.

"When people try to do thirst traps [raunchy posts] on TikTok," she says.

Cringe brings different things to mind for Jorja and Ava (left), pictured with Taylor and Aida. (BTN High: Michelle Wakim)

"Cheese grater jeans, to be honest," Jorja, 20, says.

For others, cringe is harder to define.

Noah says: "Probably something that's, like, really out of the ordinary, not just unique."

"Being cringe is like, you're sort of acting uncool," Tianyi, 19, says.

Asha, 17, says: "People just being odd in public and then people giving them strange looks makes me cringe."

Loading...
